title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the national park that has had the greatest loss of visibility as of 2015 when compared with the historical natural visibility as Sequoia National Park.

title: Part B-ii
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how a primary pollutant becomes part of the atmosphere, such as any of the following:

· Primary pollutants are released directly from a specific source, such as a smokestack, tailpipe, leaking pipelines, etc.

· Primary pollutants are released from the combustion of fossil fuels.

· Some pollutants ( CO MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGdbGaae4taaaa@37AE@ , PM MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGqbGaaeytaaaa@37B9@ ) are a result of incomplete combustion of hydrocarbons.

· Some pollutants (methane, nitrous oxide, ammonia) are released directly from a biological source, such as cows, swamps, etc.

The response describes how a primary pollutant becomes part of the atmosphere, such as one of the following:

· Primary pollutants are released directly from a specific source, such as a smokestack, tailpipe, leaking pipelines, etc.

· Primary pollutants are released from the combustion of fossil fuels.

title: Part B-iv
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how a secondary air pollutant is formed within the atmosphere, such as any of the following:

· Secondary air pollutants are formed when primary pollutants react with other compounds.

title: Part C-i
stimulusHtml:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.

Note: Students are not required to show work.
descriptions: The response does not calculate the percentage of increase in visibility from 1990 to 2015 as 80% increase in visibility.

The response calculates the percentage of increase in visibility from 1990 to 2015 as 80%

increase in visibility.

title: Part C-ii
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not discuss any specific actions that the state or federal government could take or encourage to further improve the visibility in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, such as any of the following:

· Require or offer incentives for utilities/corporations to reduce emissions by specific methods, such as cap-and-trade, pollution-prevention control devices, alternative energy sources, environmental standards on new equipment, etc.

· Limit vehicle traffic in the park through increased parking fees, free/required shuttles, HOV MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGibGaae4taiaabAfaaaa@388C@ priority parking, etc.

· Enact stricter standards for emissions on motor vehicles.

· Offer incentives to switch from gasoline-powered vehicles to electric vehicles or natural-gas powered vehicles.

· Offer tax credits or subsidies to homeowners to increase the use of renewable energy sources.

· Limit incineration practices/prohibit campfires to reduce air pollutants.

The response discusses one specific action that the state or federal government could take or encourage to further improve the visibility in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, such as one of the following:

· Require or offer incentives for utilities/corporations to reduce emissions by specific methods, such as cap-and-trade, pollution-prevention control devices, alternative energy sources, environmental standards on new equipment, etc.

· Enact stricter standards for emissions on motor vehicles.

· Offer incentives to switch from gasoline-powered vehicles to electric vehicles or natural-gas powered vehicles.

· Offer tax credits or subsidies to homeowners to increase the use of renewable energy sources.

· Limit incineration practices/prohibit campfires to reduce air pollutants.

The response discusses two specific actions that the state or federal government could take or encourage to further improve the visibility in Great Smoky Mountains National Park, such as two of the following:

· Require or offer incentives for utilities/corporations to reduce emissions by specific methods, such as cap-and-trade, pollution-prevention control devices, alternative energy sources, environmental standards on new equipment, etc.

· Limit vehicle traffic in the park through increased parking fees, free/required shuttles, HOV MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGibGaae4taiaabAfaaaa@388C@ priority parking, etc.

· Enact stricter standards for emissions on motor vehicles.

· Offer incentives to switch from gasoline-powered vehicles to electric vehicles or natural-gas powered vehicles.

· Offer tax credits or subsidies to homeowners to increase the use of renewable energy sources.

· Limit incineration practices/prohibit campfires to reduce air pollutants.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not discuss any additional ways (excluding air pollution) that national park ecosystems are being degraded by high levels of visitor use, such as any of the following:

· Littering or inappropriate disposal of trash can negatively impact the health of wildlife.

· Littering or inappropriate disposal of trash can negatively impact water quality.

· Infrastructure construction/maintenance can result in habitat fragmentation.

· Driving or walking off road/path damages vegetation, increases erosion, or increases soil compaction.

· Noise pollution can adversely impact wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Light pollution can adversely impact wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Interactions with humans or pets adversely impacts wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Visitors transporting species to the park results in an increase in invasive species.

· Camp fires from visitors can lead to wildfires.

· Removal of individual organisms for food, trophies, or human use can disrupt the food web.

· Water used for bathing and sanitation can lead to pollution of water resources.

The response discusses one additional way (excluding air pollution) that national park ecosystems are being degraded by high levels of visitor use, such as one of the following:

· Littering or inappropriate disposal of trash can negatively impact the health of wildlife.

· Littering or inappropriate disposal of trash can negatively impact water quality.

· Infrastructure construction/maintenance can result in habitat fragmentation.

· Driving or walking off road/path damages vegetation, increases erosion, or increases soil compaction.

· Noise pollution can adversely impact wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Light pollution can adversely impact wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Interactions with humans or pets adversely impacts wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Visitors transporting species to the park results in an increase in invasive species.

· Camp fires from visitors can lead to wildfires.

· Removal of individual organisms for food, trophies, or human use can disrupt the food web.

· Water used for bathing and sanitation can lead to pollution of water resources.

The response discusses two additional ways (excluding air pollution) that national park ecosystems are being degraded by high levels of visitor use, such as two of the following:

· Littering or inappropriate disposal of trash can negatively impact the health of wildlife.

· Littering or inappropriate disposal of trash can negatively impact water quality.

· Infrastructure construction/maintenance can result in habitat fragmentation.

· Driving or walking off road/path damages vegetation, increases erosion, or increases soil compaction.

· Noise pollution can adversely impact wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Light pollution can adversely impact wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Interactions with humans or pets adversely impacts wildlife by disrupting mating, ranging, foraging, etc.

· Visitors transporting species to the park results in an increase in invasive species.

· Camp fires from visitors can lead to wildfires.

· Removal of individual organisms for food, trophies, or human use can disrupt the food web.

· Water used for bathing and sanitation can lead to pollution of water resources.
